Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2: Development of a Low-Frequency Microwave Polarimeter for Large Scale Surveys
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

Throughout history and all cultures mankind has wondered about the beginnings of our universe. Today's scientific understanding of those beginnings still leaves many unanswered questions: Why is the geometry of the universe so flat? Why is the universe so homogeneous? Theoretical cosmologists have posed answers to these questions, but the theories are extremely difficult to verify. Inflation in the very early universe is now the widely accepted theoretical explanation, but empirical measurements of the subtle predictions of inflation theory are elusive. Dr. Charles Bennett of The Johns Hopkins University is building a sophisticated instrument to make a measurement of the very faint imprint on the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) that inflation theory predicts would have been made by gravitational waves. The key is to measure the anisotropy of the so-called "B mode polarization" in the CMB. This is a search for a veritable needle in a haystack and great care is required to detect and isolate the very weak distant signature from the very strong unrelated foreground signals on the sky. Dr. Bennett has designed an instrument that he suggests stands the best chance for making this measurement by targeting the scales where the signature is strongest relative to the foreground signals. Development of this instrument is funded by the National Science Foundation's Major Research Instrumentation program through the Division of Astronomical Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have built a novel telescope to address the fundamental question of how our universe began. The leading theory behind the beginning of the universe, called Inflation, involves a rapid expansion of space during which a volume smaller than an atom was stretched to the size of the observable universe. As outlandish as this may seem, the theory of Inflation is both well-motivated theoretically and accounts for many characteristics of our universe, including the observed distribution of galaxies and the measured curvature of space-time. Inflation also provides an observable connection between quantum mechanics and gravity: quantum fluctuations in the gravitational field would be expanded into gravitational waves the size of the observable universe. These gravitational waves stretch and distort space-time in the early universe, leaving a particular polarization pattern, called B-modes, in the light of the early universe. This light, called the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB), therefore holds the answer to how the universe began and the long-sought connection between quantum mechanics and gravity.

The CMB was discovered 50 years ago. It is the oldest light in the universe  and is now at microwave wavelengths. As light that has been traveling across the universe for 13.8 billion years it carries direct information about the infant universe. As a result, studies of the CMB have been the cornerstone of modern cosmology. However, the history of modern cosmology is riddled with erroneous observational results due to two primary factors: (1) systematic effects that cause spurious signals that are confused as primordial signals, and (2) local astrophysical microwaves that are confused as primordial signals. A major challenge of a new instrument is to greatly reduce these sources of confusion to produce reliable data. Another challenge is the need for high sensitivity since the microwave signal is faint and a large number of highly sensitive detectors is required.

The telescope that we have built to measure and characterize the B-mode polarization in the CMB is called the Cosmology Large Angular Scale Surveyor (CLASS). CLASS was designed to avoid the problems while achieving high sensitivity. In addition, CLASS is the only current CMB instrument capable of characterizing the full inflation signal, from the largest angular scales down to the smallest angular scales when B-modes from gravitational lensing dominates over the B-modes from Inflation.

The CLASS CMB B-mode instrument design overcomes the challenges through the invention and implementation of novel technologies. To measure the faint signal we have developed unique detectors with unmatched efficiency and control of systematic errors. We have also developed cryogenic technologies to cool these detectors and reduce thermal noise. To distinguish the primordial CMB signal from foreground signals from the emission by dust and relativistic electrons in our own galaxy CLASS observes in four widely separated frequency bands (at 40, 90, 150, and 220 GHz) that straddle the minimum of the galactic polarized emission. CLASS achieves large angular scales by use of a polarization modulator as the first optical element and by measuring the CMB polarization over 70% of the sky every day. Only signals that robustly appear repeatedly throughout the year and only signals modulated synchronously with the polarizer are accepted as genuine, and, thereby vastly reducing adverse systematic effects.
